propositions.text: A truck driver, Wu Zhiguang, intoxicated, accidentally hits and kills a pedestrian in a narrow alley.
Wu Zhiguang, in a state of semi-drunkenness, is carrying a truckload of steel.
He is rushing to deliver the cargo by 7 AM the next morning.
He encounters a friend and drinks half a jin of liquor.
He swerves into an alley to avoid a figure that suddenly appeared on the road.
Inside the alley, he hits another person.
The person hit is dead.
Wu Zhiguang realizes he has switched phones with his friend and his phone is dead.
Detective Han Feng, known for his lazy and unconventional methods, is brought into the case.
Han Feng is a tall and thin man, appearing disheveled and poor.
He lives in a dilapidated space above a hair salon.
He is initially reluctant to take the case, stating his principle is to only investigate 'earth-shattering cases'.
He is persuaded to take the case when he learns the deceased, Liang Xingsheng, recently purchased a substantial life insurance policy.
He is further motivated when he learns the insurance manager, Pan Kexin, is attractive and young.
The initial investigation suggests the death was an accident or an insurance fraud scheme.
Liang Xingsheng's company was on the verge of bankruptcy.
He had purchased an accidental death insurance policy with a high payout.
Han Feng visits the accident scene and the clothing store across the street.
He also interviews Wu Zhiguang, the truck driver.
Han Feng initially believes it to be a straightforward accident, influenced by the plight of the victim's family.
Han Feng's investigation takes a turn when he discovers inconsistencies that point towards murder.
The distinct scent of expensive French perfume on the victim's wife, Lu Fang, contradicts her impoverished circumstances.
Lu Fang's ability to hire a senior lawyer for the insurance claim suggests more than just a struggling widow.
Discrepancies in the autopsy report, particularly the minimal injuries sustained by the victim from a heavy truck collision.
The presence of multiple blood types at the scene and on collected evidence.
Evidence found on the roof of the building opposite the accident scene, suggesting a staged accident using a dummy.
The discovery of bloodstains in a narrow alley near the accident site, indicating a different sequence of events.
The case evolves into a complex murder plot involving insurance fraud.
Liang Xingsheng was likely murdered, not killed in an accident.
The staged accident was a deliberate attempt to cover up the murder and claim insurance money.
The involvement of a third party or accomplice is implied.
Han Feng predicts that more murders may follow as the investigation progresses.
The narrative sets up the formation of a special task force to investigate the deepening mystery.

hierarchy.structure: The document follows a narrative structure that begins with an inciting incident (the accident), introduces the protagonist detective and the initial premise of the case (accident/insurance fraud), and then progressively reveals deeper layers of complexity, culminating in the discovery of a premeditated murder plot. The structure is chronological and progresses through stages of investigation and revelation.
